symbols.name: os

comment.shortText: Returns the operating system CPU architecture for which the tauri app was compiled. Possible values are `'x86'`, `'x86_64'`, `'arm'`, `'aarch64'`, `'mips'`, `'mips64'`, `'powerpc'`, `'powerpc64'`, `'riscv64'`, `'s390x'`, `'sparc64'`

Returns a string identifying the operating system platform.
The value is set at compile time. Possible values are `'linux'`, `'darwin'`, `'ios'`, `'freebsd'`, `'dragonfly'`, `'netbsd'`, `'openbsd'`, `'solaris'`, `'android'`, `'win32'`
Returns the operating system's default directory for temporary files as a string.
Returns `'Linux'` on Linux, `'Darwin'` on macOS, and `'Windows_NT'` on Windows.
Returns a string identifying the kernel version.

symbols.name: path

comment.shortText:
Returns the path to the suggested directory for your app config files.
Resolves to `${configDir}/${bundleIdentifier}`, where `bundleIdentifier` is the value configured on `tauri.conf.json > tauri > bundle > identifier`.
Returns the path to the user's audio directory.
comment.text:
#### Platform-specific

- **Linux:** Resolves to [`xdg-user-dirs`](https://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Software/xdg-user-dirs/)' `XDG_MUSIC_DIR`.
- **macOS:** Resolves to `$HOME/Music`.
- **Windows:** Resolves to `{FOLDERID_Music}`.

comment.shortText: Returns the last portion of a `path`. Trailing directory separators are ignored.
Returns the path to the user's cache directory.
comment.text:
#### Platform-specific

- **Linux:** Resolves to `$XDG_CACHE_HOME` or `$HOME/.cache`.
- **macOS:** Resolves to `$HOME/Library/Caches`.
- **Windows:** Resolves to `{FOLDERID_LocalAppData}`.

comment.shortText: Returns the path to the user's config directory.
comment.text:
#### Platform-specific

- **Linux:** Resolves to `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME` or `$HOME/.config`.
- **macOS:** Resolves to `$HOME/Library/Application Support`.
- **Windows:** Resolves to `{FOLDERID_LocalAppData}`.

comment.shortText: Returns the path to the user's data directory.
comment.text:
#### Platform-specific

- **Linux:** Resolves to `$XDG_DATA_HOME` or `$HOME/.local/share`.
- **macOS:** Resolves to `$HOME/Library/Application Support`.
- **Windows:** Resolves to `{FOLDERID_RoamingAppData}`.

comment.shortText: Returns the path to the user's desktop directory.
comment.text:
#### Platform-specific

- **Linux:** Resolves to [`xdg-user-dirs`](https://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Software/xdg-user-dirs/)' `XDG_DESKTOP_DIR`.
- **macOS:** Resolves to `$HOME/Library/Desktop`.
- **Windows:** Resolves to `{FOLDERID_Desktop}`.

comment.shortText: Returns the directory name of a `path`. Trailing directory separators are ignored.
Returns the path to the user's document directory.
comment.text:

- **Linux:** Resolves to [`xdg-user-dirs`](https://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Software/xdg-user-dirs/)' `XDG_DOCUMENTS_DIR`.
- **macOS:** Resolves to `$HOME/Documents`.
- **Windows:** Resolves to `{FOLDERID_Documents}`.

comment.shortText: Returns the path to the user's download directory.

- **Windows**: Resolves to `{FOLDERID_Downloads}`.

comment.shortText: Returns the path to the user's executable directory.
comment.text:
#### Platform-specific

- **Linux:** Resolves to `$XDG_BIN_HOME/../bin` or `$XDG_DATA_HOME/../bin` or `$HOME/.local/bin`.
- **macOS:** Not supported.
- **Windows:** Not supported.

comment.shortText: Returns the extension of the `path`.
Returns the path to the user's font directory.

comment.shortText: Returns the path to the user's home directory.
comment.text:
#### Platform-specific

- **Linux:** Resolves to `$HOME`.
- **macOS:** Resolves to `$HOME`.
- **Windows:** Resolves to `{FOLDERID_Profile}`.

comment.shortText: Joins all given `path` segments together using the platform-specific separator as a delimiter, then normalizes the resulting path.

- **macOS:** Resolves to `$HOME/Library/Application Support`.

comment.shortText: Returns the path to the suggested log directory.
comment.text:

- **Linux:** Resolves to `${configDir}/${bundleIdentifier}`.
- **macOS:** Resolves to `${homeDir}//Library/Logs/{bundleIdentifier}`
- **Windows:** Resolves to `${configDir}/${bundleIdentifier}`.

symbols.name: shell
symbols.comment:
This package is also accessible with `window.__TAURI__.shell` when `tauri.conf.json > build > withGlobalTauri` is set to true.

The APIs must be allowlisted on `tauri.conf.json`:
```json
{
  "tauri": {
    "allowlist": {
      "shell": {
        "all": true, // enable all shell APIs
        "execute": true, // enable process spawn APIs
        "sidecar": true, // enable spawning sidecars
        "open": true // enable opening files/URLs using the default program
      }
    }
  }
}
```
It is recommended to allowlist only the APIs you use for optimal bundle size and security.

## Security

This API has a scope configuration that forces you to restrict the programs and arguments that can be used.

### Restricting access to the [[`open`]] API

On the allowlist, `open: true` means that the [[open]] API can be used with any URL,
as the argument is validated with the `^https?://` regex.
You can change that regex by changing the boolean value to a string, e.g. `open: ^https://github.com/`.

### Restricting access to the [[`Command`]] APIs

The `shell` allowlist object has a `scope` field that defines an array of CLIs that can be used.
Each CLI is a configuration object `{ name: string, command: string, sidecar?: bool, args?: boolean | Arg[] }`.

- `name`: the unique identifier of the command, passed to the [[Command.constructor | Command constructor]].
If it's a sidecar, this must be the value defined on `tauri.conf.json > tauri > bundle > externalBin`.
- `command`: the program that is executed on this configuration. If it's a sidecar, it must be the same as `name`.
- `sidecar`: whether the object configures a sidecar or a system program.
- `args`: the arguments that can be passed to the program. By default no arguments are allowed.
  - `true` means that any argument list is allowed.
  - `false` means that no arguments are allowed.
  - otherwise an array can be configured. Each item is either a string representing the fixed argument value
    or a `{ validator: string }` that defines a regex validating the argument value.

#### Example scope configuration

CLI: `git commit -m "the commit message"`

Configuration:
```json
{
  "scope": {
    "name": "run-git-commit",
    "command": "git",
    "args": ["commit", "-m", { "validator": "\\S+" }]
  }
}
```
Usage:
```typescript
import { Command } from '@tauri-apps/api/shell'
new Command('run-git-commit', ['commit', '-m', 'the commit message'])
```

Trying to execute any API with a program not configured on the scope results in a promise rejection due to denied access.

tags.text:
```typescript
const output = await new Command('echo', 'message').execute()
assert(output.code === 0)
assert(output.signal === null)
assert(output.stdout === 'message')
assert(output.stderr === '')
```

symbols.name: tauri
symbols.comment: This package is also accessible with `window.__TAURI__.tauri` when `tauri.conf.json > build > withGlobalTauri` is set to true.

comment.shortText:
Convert a device file path to an URL that can be loaded by the webview.
Note that `asset:` and `https://asset.localhost` must be allowed on the `csp` value configured on `tauri.conf.json > tauri > security`.
Example CSP value: `"csp": "default-src 'self'; img-src 'self' asset: https://asset.localhost"` to use the asset protocol on image sources.
comment.text:
Additionally, the `asset` must be allowlisted under `tauri.conf.json > tauri > allowlist > protocol`,
and its access scope must be defined on the `assetScope` array on the same `protocol` object.
comment.returns: the URL that can be used as source on the webview.

comment.returns: A promise resolving or rejecting to the backend response.

comment.shortText:

The backend uses the identifier to `eval()` the callback.
comment.returns: A unique identifier associated with the callback function.

symbols.name: window
symbols.comment:
This package is also accessible with `window.__TAURI__.window` when `tauri.conf.json > build > withGlobalTauri` is set to true.

The APIs must be allowlisted on `tauri.conf.json`:
```json
{
  "tauri": {
    "allowlist": {
      "window": {
        "all": true, // enable all window APIs
        "create": true, // enable window creation
        "center": true,
        "requestUserAttention": true,
        "setResizable": true,
        "setTitle": true,
        "maximize": true,
        "unmaximize": true,
        "minimize": true,
        "unminimize": true,
        "show": true,
        "hide": true,
        "close": true,
        "setDecorations": true,
        "setAlwaysOnTop": true,
        "setSize": true,
        "setMinSize": true,
        "setMaxSize": true,
        "setPosition": true,
        "setFullscreen": true,
        "setFocus": true,
        "setIcon": true,
        "setSkipTaskbar": true,
        "startDragging": true,
        "print": true
      }
    }
  }
}
```
It is recommended to allowlist only the APIs you use for optimal bundle size and security.

# Window events

Events can be listened using `appWindow.listen`:
```typescript
import { appWindow } from '@tauri-apps/api/window'
appWindow.listen('tauri://move', ({ event, payload }) => {
  const { x, y } = payload // payload here is a `PhysicalPosition`
})
```

Window-specific events emitted by the backend:

#### 'tauri://resize'
Emitted when the size of the window has changed.
*EventPayload*:
```typescript
type ResizePayload = PhysicalSize
```

#### 'tauri://move'
Emitted when the position of the window has changed.
*EventPayload*:
```typescript
type MovePayload = PhysicalPosition
```

#### 'tauri://close-requested'
Emitted when the user requests the window to be closed.
If a listener is registered for this event, Tauri won't close the window so you must call `appWindow.close()` manually.

#### 'tauri://focus'
Emitted when the window gains focus.

#### 'tauri://blur'
Emitted when the window loses focus.

#### 'tauri://scale-change'
Emitted when the window's scale factor has changed.
The following user actions can cause DPI changes:
- Changing the display's resolution.
- Changing the display's scale factor (e.g. in Control Panel on Windows).
- Moving the window to a display with a different scale factor.
*Event payload*:
```typescript
interface ScaleFactorChanged {
  scaleFactor: number
  size: PhysicalSize
}
```

#### 'tauri://menu'
Emitted when a menu item is clicked.
*EventPayload*:
```typescript
type MenuClicked = string
```

- **Windows:** Flashes both the window and the taskbar button until the application is in focus.

Providing `null` will unset the request for user attention. Unsetting the request for
user attention might not be done automatically by the WM when the window receives input.

- **macOS:** `null` has no effect.
- **Linux:** Urgency levels have the same effect.

Sets the window maximum inner size. If the `size` argument is undefined, the constraint is unset.
comment.returns: A promise indicating the success or failure of the operation.

tags.text:
```typescript
import { appWindow, LogicalSize } from '@tauri-apps/api/window'
await appWindow.setMaxSize(new LogicalSize(600, 500))
```

comment.shortText: Gets the WebviewWindow for the webview associated with the given label.
comment.returns: The WebviewWindow instance to communicate with the webview or null if the webview doesn't exist.

comment.shortText: The webview window label.
The window label. It is a unique identifier for the window, can be used to reference it later.
Local event listeners.
Emits an event to the backend, tied to the webview window.
Event name. Must include only alphanumeric characters, `-`, `/`, `:` and `_`.
Event payload.
Listen to an event emitted by the backend that is tied to the webview window.
comment.returns: A promise resolving to a function to unlisten to the event.

comment.shortText: Event name. Must include only alphanumeric characters, `-`, `/`, `:` and `_`.
Event handler.
Listen to an one-off event emitted by the backend that is tied to the webview window.
comment.returns: A promise resolving to a function to unlisten to the event.

comment.shortText: Event name. Must include only alphanumeric characters, `-`, `/`, `:` and `_`.
Event handler.

Local event listeners.
Centers the window.
comment.returns: A promise indicating the success or failure of the operation.

comment.shortText: Closes the window.

comment.shortText: Emits an event to the backend, tied to the webview window.
Event name. Must include only alphanumeric characters, `-`, `/`, `:` and `_`.
Event payload.
Sets the window visibility to false.
comment.returns: A promise indicating the success or failure of the operation.

comment.shortText: The position of the top-left hand corner of the window's client area relative to the top-left hand corner of the desktop.

The physical size of the window's client area.
The client area is the content of the window, excluding the title bar and borders.
Gets the window's current decorated state.
Gets the window's current fullscreen state.
Gets the window's current maximized state.
Gets the window's current resizable state.
Gets the window's current visible state.
Listen to an event emitted by the backend that is tied to the webview window.
comment.returns: A promise resolving to a function to unlisten to the event.

comment.shortText: Event name. Must include only alphanumeric characters, `-`, `/`, `:` and `_`.
Event handler.
Maximizes the window.

comment.shortText: Minimizes the window.

comment.shortText: Listen to an one-off event emitted by the backend that is tied to the webview window.
comment.returns: A promise resolving to a function to unlisten to the event.

comment.shortText: Event name. Must include only alphanumeric characters, `-`, `/`, `:` and `_`.
Event handler.
The position of the top-left hand corner of the window relative to the top-left hand corner of the desktop.

The physical size of the entire window.
These dimensions include the title bar and borders. If you don't want that (and you usually don't), use inner_size instead.

Requests user attention to the window, this has no effect if the application
is already focused. How requesting for user attention manifests is platform dependent,
see `UserAttentionType` for details.
comment.text:
Providing `null` will unset the request for user attention. Unsetting the request for
user attention might not be done automatically by the WM when the window receives input.

#### Platform-specific

- **macOS:** `null` has no effect.
- **Linux:** Urgency levels have the same effect.
comment.returns: A promise indicating the success or failure of the operation.

comment.shortText: The scale factor that can be used to map physical pixels to logical pixels.
Whether the window should always be on top of other windows.
comment.returns: A promise indicating the success or failure of the operation.

comment.shortText: Whether the window should always be on top of other windows or not.
Whether the window should have borders and bars.
comment.returns: A promise indicating the success or failure of the operation.

comment.shortText: Human-readable name of the monitor
the Top-left corner position of the monitor relative to the larger full screen area.
The scale factor that can be used to map physical pixels to logical pixels.
The monitor's resolution.
Whether the window should always be on top of other windows or not.
Show window in the center of the screen..
Whether the window should have borders and bars or not.
Whether the file drop is enabled or not on the webview. By default it is enabled.
comment.text: Disabling it is required to use drag and drop on the frontend on Windows.

comment.shortText: Whether the window will be initially hidden or focused.
Whether the window is in fullscreen mode or not.
The initial height.
The maximum height. Only applies if `maxWidth` is also set.
The maximum width. Only applies if `maxHeight` is also set.
Whether the window should be maximized upon creation or not.
The minimum height. Only applies if `minWidth` is also set.
The minimum width. Only applies if `minHeight` is also set.
Whether the window is resizable or not.
Whether or not the window icon should be added to the taskbar.
Window title.

Whether the window is transparent or not.
Note that on `macOS` this requires the `macos-private-api` feature flag, enabled under `tauri.conf.json > tauri > macosPrivateApi`.
WARNING: Using private APIs on `macOS` prevents your application from being accepted for the `App Store`.
Remote URL or local file path to open.
comment.text:
- URL such as `https://github.com/tauri-apps` is opened directly on a Tauri window.
- data: URL such as `data:text/html,<html>...` is only supported with the `window-data-url` Cargo feature for the `tauri` dependency.
- local file path or route such as `/path/to/page.html` or `/users` is appended to the application URL (the devServer URL on development, or `tauri://localhost/` and `https://tauri.localhost/` on production).

comment.shortText: Whether the window should be immediately visible upon creation or not.
The initial width.
The initial vertical position. Only applies if `y` is also set.
The initial horizontal position. Only applies if `x` is also set.
Returns the list of all the monitors available on the system.

Returns the monitor on which the window currently resides.
Returns `null` if current monitor can't be detected.
Gets an instance of `WebviewWindow` for all available webview windows.
comment.returns: The list of WebviewWindow.

comment.shortText: Get an instance of `WebviewWindow` for the current webview window.
comment.returns: The current WebviewWindow.

comment.shortText:
Returns the primary monitor of the system.
Returns `null` if it can't identify any monitor as a primary one.
